Just a shadow.** - **Ending:** Meg’s phone **vibrates**. *"You’re next."* **Tone:** **Gothic, claustrophobic.** The **woods feel alive**. Meg’s **humor cracks**. --- #### **Chapter 3: The Body in the Gym** - **The Bet:** The school is **obsessed**—students are **betting on who the killer is**. Meg is **favorite**. - **Break-In:** Meg and Priya **break into the old gym** (rumored to be **haunted**). They find **a rotting body**—wearing **Meg’s old uniform**. - **Discovery:** The body has **no face**, but **a phone in its pocket**—inside, a **video of Meg’s mum**. - **Twist:** The **Lantern Club’s logo** is carved into the floor. - **Ending:** Meg’s phone **lights up**: *"Find the ledger."* **Tone:** **Body horror, dark humor.** The **students treat this like a game**, but Meg is **terrified**. --- #### **Chapter 4: The Ledger** - **The Hunt:** Meg and Priya **search the school**, finding **clues** (e.g., a **student’s diary** with *"The next sacrifice must be pure"*). - **The Ledger:** They find a **hidden room** with a **ledger**—listing **names of past victims… and Meg’s at the bottom**. - **Reveal:** The **last entry** is **Jake’s name**, dated **next week**. - **Betrayal:** Priya **hesitates**—then **smashes the ledger**. *"We’re not telling anyone."* - **Ending:** Meg’s phone **vibrates**: *"Priya knows. Do you trust her?"* **Tone:** **Paranoia, moral dilemma.** Meg is **betrayed by her best friend**. --- #### **Chapter 5: The Dance Recital** - **The Plan:** The Lantern Club **announces a dance recital**—a **front for a ritual**. - **The Trap:** Meg is **forced to perform**, but **Lila (the queen bee) is the real target**. - **The Possession:** During the performance, **Lila starts screaming**—her **eyes turn black**. She **lunges at Meg**. - **Escape:** Meg **fights back**, but **Lila’s body starts melting** (revealed later to be **the ghost possessing her**). - **Ending:** The **headmaster covers it up**—*"Accident. Move on."*—but Meg’s phone **vibrates**: *"You’re not safe yet."* **Tone:** **Gothic horror, absurdity.** The **dance recital is a nightmare**. --- #### **Chapter 6: The Truth About the Ghost** - **The Investigation:** Meg **hacks the school’s old records** and finds **a student died in 1999**—**same age as her mum**. - **The Connection:** Her mum was **investigating the school** before she died. - **The Ghost’s Offer:** Meg’s phone **starts talking to her**: *"Join me. You’ll never be lonely again."* - **The Choice:** Meg **texts back**: *"I’m scared."* The ghost **can’t harm her**—but it’s **angry**. - **Ending:** Meg’s **skin starts peeling off** in strips—**the ghost’s "punishment."** **Tone:** **Psychological horror, tragic.** The ghost is **not evil—it’s sad**. --- #### **Chapter 7: The Lantern Club’s Secret** - **The Confrontation:** Meg **blackmails Jake** into revealing the **Lantern Club’s rituals**. - **The Ritual:** They **kill a student every decade** to **"reset" the school’s luck**. - **The Twist:** The **ghost is the last victim**, and it **doesn’t want to kill Meg—it wants her to free it**. - **The Plan:** Meg **needs to perform a ritual**—but it involves **sacrificing someone**. - **Ending:** Priya **walks in**—*"I knew you’d do something stupid."* **She’s holding a knife.** **Tone:** **Betrayal, desperation.** Meg is **cornered**. --- #### **Chapter 8: The Final Text** - **The Sacrifice:** Meg **realizes Priya is in on it**—she’s **the next sacrifice**. - **The Ritual:** Meg **pretends to go along with it**, but **tricks the ghost** into **possessing Priya instead**. - **The Escape:** The ghost **is now trapped in Priya**, screaming *"Let me out!"* as Meg **smashes her phone**. - **The Aftermath:** The school **covers it up**. Jake **gets away with it**. - **The Final Text:** Meg’s **new phone lights up**—*"You’re free now."* **Then a fourth emoji appears: 🩸🩸🩸🩸.** - **Ending:** Meg **laughs**, but the **camera pans to her reflection**—**her eyes are black for a second**. **Tone:** **Ambiguous, eerie.** The **horror isn’t over**. --- ### **Key Stylistic Choices** - **Meg’s Voice:** **Sarcastic, exhausted, but with sudden moments of horror.** Example: *"Great. Another text. This time it just said ‘🩸🩸🩸.’ Like I don’t have enough to worry about. My dad’s embezzling, my best friend’s selling my secrets, and now my phone’s possessed. Typical Tuesday."* - **Pacing:** **Short, punchy chapters** with **cliffhangers**. Each chapter **escalates the horror**. - **Horror Elements:** - **Body horror** (peeling skin, melting faces). - **Psychological horror** (texts that shouldn’t exist). - **Social horror** (students treating this like a game). - **Comedy Elements:** - **Meg’s internal monologue** (e.g., *"The headmaster’s corgi ate my homework. Or maybe it was the ghost. Hard to tell."*). - **Absurd situations** (e.g., a **murder mystery dinner** where the **real killer is the dessert**). --- ### **Final Notes** - **The Ghost’s Motivation:** It’s **lonely and wants company**, not just revenge. - **The Lantern Club:** They’re **not masterminds—they’re just cruel kids who think they’re better**. - **Meg’s Arc:** She **starts as a cynic**, but by the end, she’s **not sure what’s real anymore**. This plan keeps the **dark comedy**, **British sharpness**, and **gothic horror** while avoiding **over-explaining** the supernatural. The **ending is ambiguous**—the **horror lingers**, and Meg is **changed but not "saved."**
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
### **How a Human Might Approach This Piece (vs. LLM Tendencies)** The original prompt—**three blood emojis at midnight**—is **deliciously ambiguous**, **visceral**, and **open to deep human interpretation**. A human writer would likely approach it with: 1. **Uncertainty & Messiness** - A human might **hesitate** before committing to a single interpretation (ghost? cult? gaslighting?). They’d **explore false leads**, **change their mind mid-way**, and **embrace contradictions**. - Example: They might start with a **psychological horror angle** (Meg’s grief manifesting as hallucinations), then **shift to supernatural**, then **realize it’s a mix of both**. 2. **Emotional & Sensory Specificity** - A human would **ground the horror in physical, visceral details**—the **smell of damp wood** in the school’s abandoned wing, the **taste of copper** when Meg cuts her lip, the **weight of a phone** in her trembling hand. - They’d **avoid abstract descriptions** in favor of **concrete, awkward, human moments** (e.g., Meg **accidentally texting "I love you" to the wrong number** because her hands are shaking). 3. **Character-Driven Detours** - A human might **derail the plot** for a **suddenly relevant memory**—Meg remembering her mum burning toast, or Priya **snapping at her for no reason**, or Jake **laughing too loud at a joke that wasn’t funny**. - These **seemingly irrelevant moments** would **deeply inform the horror** (e.g., the ghost **mimics Priya’s voice** because it’s been listening). 4. **Ambiguity & Unanswered Questions** - A human would **leave things unresolved**—not because they’re lazy, but because **life is unresolved**. The ghost’s motive might **never be fully explained**. Meg might **never know if Priya was truly betraying her or possessed**. - Example: The **fourth blood emoji** at the end isn’t just a sequel hook—it’s **a human fear**: *The thing you thought was over isn’t.* 5. **Dark Comedy That Feels Earned** - A human’s humor would **come from character, not setup**. Meg’s jokes wouldn’t be **clever for the sake of cleverness**—they’d be **defensive, exhausted, or cruel**. - Example: Instead of a **witty one-liner**, Meg might **laugh at a funeral**, then **realize she’s crying and stop abruptly**. 6. **Pacing That Mimics Human Anxiety** - A human’s pacing would **spiral**—some chapters would **drag with paranoia**, others would **zoom past in a panic**. - Example: A chapter where **nothing happens** (Meg waits for a text that never comes) would be **just as terrifying** as a chapter with **body horror**. 7. **Avoiding "Impressive" Writing** - A human would **avoid purple prose** in favor of **clunky, real dialogue** (e.g., *"Yeah, well, your mum’s a liar too"* instead of *"Your maternal lineage is a fabric of deceit"*). - They’d **write the way people actually talk**—**interrupting themselves**, **trailing off**, **using filler words**. 8. **Moral Gray Areas** - A human wouldn’t **force a clear "good vs. evil"**—the **ghost might be sympathetic**, the **Lantern Club members might be trauma survivors**, Meg might **do something terrible by the end**. - Example: Meg **lets Priya be possessed** to save herself—is she a **villain or a survivor**? 9. **Cultural & Class Nuance** - A human would **weave in real British details**—**the way people queue**, **the way they talk about the weather**, **the way they avoid direct confrontation**. - Example: Instead of *"I’m scared"*, Meg might say *"I’m a bit knackered, innit?"* when she’s actually **terrified**. 10. **The Horror Feels Personal** - A human would **tie the supernatural to Meg’s real trauma**—the ghost isn’t just **haunting her**, it’s **mimicking her mum’s voice** because it’s **obsessed with her grief**. - Example: The ghost **sends her a photo of her mum’s wedding ring**—but it’s **covered in blood**. --- ### **LLM Pitfalls in the Current Plan** Here’s where the **current outline risks falling into LLM traps**: #### **1. Over-Reliance on Exposition** - **Problem:** The **Lantern Club’s rules**, the **ghost’s backstory**, and the **school’s history** are **explained too neatly**. - **LLM Tendency:** LLMs **love structure**—they’ll **lay out the mystery in clear steps** (e.g., *"Chapter 3: The Ledger Reveal"*). - **Human Fix:** **Hide the rules**. Let Meg **discover them piecemeal**, misinterpret them, or **never fully understand**. - Example: Instead of a **ledger with names**, maybe Meg finds **a yearbook with faces crossed out in red pen**—but **no names**. #### **2. Neat Escalation** - **Problem:** The horror **escalates in a clear arc** (texts → body → ghost → ritual). - **LLM Tendency:** LLMs **prefer logical progression**—they’ll **build tension predictably**. - **Human Fix:** **Spike and collapse**. Let the **horror peak early**, then **retreat into mundanity** (e.g., a **false scare** where Meg thinks she’s being followed, but it’s just **a drunk parent**). - Example: Meg **sees a shadow**—it’s **just the janitor**, but now she’s **paranoid for days**. #### **3. Too Much Control Over the Supernatural** - **Problem:** The ghost **obeys clear rules** (e.g., *"It can’t harm you if you text ‘I’m scared’"*). - **LLM Tendency:** LLMs **love systems**—they’ll **invent rules for the supernatural** to make it **feel logical**. - **Human Fix:** **The rules should be arbitrary and cruel**. The ghost **might let Meg live**—but only because **it’s bored**. - Example: The ghost **lets Meg keep her phone**—but now **it’s sending texts to her contacts**. #### **4. Character Arcs That Feel Resolved** - **Problem:** Meg **starts cynical, ends "changed"** (but still cynical). - **LLM Tendency:** LLMs **prefer clear character arcs**—**growth, fall, redemption**. - **Human Fix:** **Meg doesn’t change**. She **adapts**. By the end, she’s **not better—she’s just more jaded**. - Example: Meg **stops caring if she’s safe**—she **wants the ghost to come back** because **it’s less lonely than being human**. #### **5. Dialogue That Feels Too Polished** - **Problem:** The dialogue **serves the plot** (e.g., *"Priya: ‘We need to find the ledger.’"*). - **LLM Tendency:** LLMs **write dialogue that’s efficient**—it **moves the story forward**. - **Human Fix:** **Dialogue should be awkward, repetitive, or meaningless**. - Example: **Priya:** *"You look like shit."* **Meg:** *"Yeah, well, you’re not exactly winning any beauty pageants."* **Priya:** *"Fuck off."* *(Silence. A phone buzzes.)* #### **6. The Ending Feels Like a Sequel Hook** - **Problem:** The **fourth blood emoji** is **clearly setting up a sequel**. - **LLM Tendency:** LLMs **love cliffhangers**—they’ll **end on a clear next step**. - **Human Fix:** **The ending should feel inevitable, not like a setup**. - Example: The **fourth emoji isn’t a threat—it’s a relief**. The ghost is **finally happy** because Meg **stopped fighting it**. #### **7. The Horror Feels Generic** - **Problem:** The **ghost + cult + haunted school** trope is **well-worn**. - **LLM Tendency:** LLMs **default to familiar structures**—they’ll **mix tropes** without **fresh execution**. - **Human Fix:** **Subvert expectations**. The **ghost isn’t the main villain**—the **real horror is the school’s indifference**. - Example: The **headmaster knows** about the killings but **does nothing** because **it keeps the school’s reputation clean**. #### **8. Meg’s Voice Feels Like a Performance** - **Problem:** Meg’s **sarcasm is consistent**—she’s **always funny, always cynical**. - **LLM Tendency:** LLMs **create consistent character voices**—they’ll **stick to a tone**. - **Human Fix:** **Meg’s humor should crack**. She **laughs at the wrong times**, **forgets how to be funny**, or **starts believing her own jokes**. - Example: Meg **makes a joke about death**—then **realizes she’s crying** and **stops mid-sentence**. --- ### **Brainstorming: How to Make This More Human** #### **1. Mess Up the Structure** - **Instead of:** A **clear escalation** (texts → body → ghost → ritual). - **Try:** - **A false scare** (Meg thinks she’s being followed, but it’s just **a fox**). - **A chapter where nothing happens** (Meg waits for a text that never comes, **her anxiety spiraling**). - **A red herring** (The **janitor is actually the killer**—but it’s **just a prank gone wrong**). #### **2. Ground the Supernatural in the Mundane** - **Instead of:** The ghost **appears dramatically**. - **Try:** - The ghost **makes Meg’s phone **lag** when she’s **thinking about her mum**. - Meg **finds a photo of her mum** in her **school locker**—but **no one else remembers putting it there**. - The ghost **mimics Priya’s laugh**—but **Priya is in another room**. #### **3. Make the Horror Personal (and Ugly)** - **Instead of:** The ghost **wants revenge**. - **Try:** - The ghost **wants Meg to join it** because **it’s lonely**. - The ghost **mimics Meg’s mum’s voice** because **it’s obsessed with her grief**. - The ghost **doesn’t kill Meg**—it **makes her life worse** (e.g., **ruins her exams**, **makes her dad lose his job**). #### **4. Break the Fourth Wall (Subtly)** - **Instead of:** Meg **narrates her thoughts clearly**. - **Try:** - Meg **forgets what she was going to say** mid-sentence. - Meg **writes a text to herself** and **accidentally sends it**. - Meg **starts a story** in her head, but **it’s about someone else**. #### **5. Make the Dialogue Feel Real (and Awkward)** - **Instead of:** *"Priya: ‘We need to find the ledger.’"* - **Try:** - **Priya:** *"You’re being a twat."* **Meg:** *"Yeah, well, you’re not exactly Mother Teresa."* **Priya:** *"Fair."* *(They both look at Meg’s phone. Silence.)* - **Jake (smirking):** *"You okay?"* **Meg:** *"Peachy. Just having a lovely chat with a ghost."* **Jake:** *"…What?"* **Meg:** *"Nothing. Carry on."* #### **6. Let the Characters Fail at Understanding** - **Instead of:** Meg **figures out the ghost’s rules**. - **Try:** - Meg **misinterprets everything** (e.g., she thinks the ghost **hates her**, but it’s **just confused**). - Meg **does something "right"** (e.g., texts *"I’m scared"*)—but **it backfires** because the ghost **misunderstands**. - Meg **never fully understands**—she just **learns to live with it**. #### **7. Make the School Feel Like a Character** - **Instead of:** The school is **just a setting**. - **Try:** - The **school’s walls are always damp**. - The **lights flicker** when no one’s looking. - The **students all know things they shouldn’t** (e.g., *"Oh, you didn’t know about the old gym?"*). #### **8. End on a Human Note (Not a Cliffhanger)** - **Instead of:** *"The fourth emoji appeared."* - **Try:** - Meg **smashes her phone**—but **the emoji was just a scratch**. - Meg **starts a new school**, but **her new phone has the same issue**. - Meg **laughs**, but **no one joins in**. #### **9. Add a Twist That Feels Earned (Not Shocking)** - **Instead of:** *"The ghost was the headmaster all along."* - **Try:** - The **ghost is Meg’s mum**—but **she’s not dead, she’s trapped**. - The **Lantern Club is just kids copying a TikTok trend**. - The **real horror is that nothing happens**—the ghost **vanishes**, and Meg **never knows why**. #### **10. Make the Reader Uncomfortable (Not Just Scared)** - **Instead of:** *"The ghost is terrifying."* - **Try:** - The **ghost is sad**, and Meg **feels guilty for wanting it gone**. - The **school’s indifference is worse than the ghost**. - Meg **does something terrible** (e.g., **lets Priya be possessed**) and **doesn’t feel bad about it**. --- ### **Final Thoughts: How to Avoid LLM Traps** 1. **Embrace the messy.** Let the **plot spiral**, the **characters contradict themselves**, and the **rules of the supernatural be unclear**. 2. **Ground the horror in the human.** The **ghost shouldn’t just be scary—it should feel personal**. 3. **Make the dialogue awkward.** People **interrupt, trail off, and say stupid things**. 4. **Avoid neat resolutions.** The **ending should feel real, not like a setup**. 5. **Let the characters fail.** They **misunderstand, panic, and make things worse**. 6. **Make the setting feel alive.** The **school should have its own personality**—creepy, indifferent, or even **helpful in a weird way**. 7. **Don’t explain everything.** Some things **should stay mysterious**. 8. **Make the horror feel earned.** The **ghost shouldn’t just appear—it should feel like it’s been there all along**. --- ### **Next Steps (If We Were Rewriting)** - **Cut the "ledger reveal"**—instead, **Meg finds a yearbook with faces crossed out**. - **Make the ghost’s motive unclear**—is it **lonely, angry, or just bored**? - **Add a false scare** (e.g., Meg **thinks she’s being followed**, but it’s **just a drunk parent**). - **Make Meg’s humor crack**—she **laughs at the wrong times**, **forgets how to be funny**. - **End on a human note**—not a **cliffhanger**, but something **small and sad**. This would make the story **feel more like a human experience**—**messy, personal, and unsettling**.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
--- ### **Intention** #### **Core Purpose: Serving the Original Prompt** The **three blood emojis** must remain the **central, unshakable hook**—not just a MacGuffin, but a **living, breathing threat** that **evolves organically** from something cryptic to something **visceral and personal**. The prompt demands: - **Mystery** (What do they mean?) - **Dread** (Why are they targeting *me*?) - **Ambiguity** (Are they real, or am I losing it?) - **Dark comedy** (Because if I’m not laughing, I’ll scream.) **Key Choice:** The blood emojis **aren’t just messages—they’re a relationship**. The ghost (or whatever it is) **communicates in its own way**, and Meg **learns to respond**. It’s **not a game—it’s a negotiation**. --- #### **Human-Centric Choices** 1. **The Horror is Psychological First** - The blood emojis **start as a glitch**, then **become a voice**, then **a presence**. - Meg’s **grief (her mum’s death) is the key**—the ghost (or her subconscious) **uses the emojis to mirror her trauma**. - **Avoid:** Making the supernatural too "cool." This should **feel like a violation**, not a puzzle. 2. **The Tone: Dark Comedy as a Shield** - Meg’s **sarcasm is a defense mechanism**, but it **cracks under pressure**. - **Example:** She jokes about the blood emojis—until she **finds one carved into her own wrist**. - **Avoid:** Forced humor. The comedy should **emerge from character**, not setup. 3. **The Setting: A Character Itself** - **St. Aldwyn’s Academy** is **decaying prestige**—the **facade of elitism hides rot**. - The **woods, the old gym, the janitor’s closet**—each location **feels alive** (or haunted). - **Avoid:** Generic "haunted school" tropes. The horror should **feel tied to class, privilege, and isolation**. 4. **The Antagonist: Not Just a Monster** - The **ghost is a projection of Meg’s guilt and loneliness**. - It **doesn’t just want to kill her—it wants her to *join* it** (because it’s **lonely too**). - **Avoid:** A neat "good vs. evil" battle. The conflict is **internal and ambiguous**. 5. **The Characters: Flawed, Messy, Human** - **Meg:** Not a "chosen one," but a **kid who’s already broken**. - **Priya:** Her best friend is **not pure—she’s complicit**, but not evil. - **Jake:** The ex isn’t just a villain—he’s **part of the system** (the school, the privilege). - **Avoid:** Clear-cut allies/enemies. Everyone is **complicated**. 6. **The Pacing: Anxiety, Not Escalation** - **Not:** "Chapter 3: The Body is Found!" - **Instead:** "Chapter 3: Meg Waits for a Text That Never Comes." - **Avoid:** Predictable horror beats. The **real terror is the silence**. 7. **The Ending: No Resolution, Only Adaptation** - Meg **doesn’t "defeat" the ghost—she learns to live with it**. - The **fourth blood emoji isn’t a sequel hook—it’s a sign she’s given up**. - **Avoid:** Neat endings. The **horror should linger**, like a **text you can’t delete**. --- #### **Stylistic Choices** | **Do** | **Avoid** | |--------|-----------| | **Short, punchy sentences** for panic. | **Purple prose**—keep it **clunky and real**. | | **Dialogue that feels interrupted, trailing off, or awkward.** | **Polished exchanges**—people **stumble**. | | **Sensory details** (the **smell of bleach**, the **taste of blood**). | **Abstract descriptions**—**ground it in the body**. | | **Meg’s voice cracks**—she **laughs at the wrong time**, **forgets how to joke**. | **Consistent sarcasm**—her humor should **break**. | | **The supernatural feels *almost* explainable, but never fully.** | **Clear rules for the ghost**—it should **feel arbitrary and cruel**. | | **The school feels like a character**—**indifferent, judgmental, alive.** | **Generic "haunted school" tropes**—make it **specific to class and trauma**. | --- ### **Chapter Planning** #### **Chapter 1: The First Text (1000 words)** - **Opening:** Meg wakes at **3:17 AM** to **three blood emojis**. She **screenshots it**, thinking it’s a **glitch**—but her **ex, Jake**, texts her: *"You’re late for detention."* **No, he didn’t.** - **Investigation:** She **checks her phone’s history**—**no one else has the text**. She **asks Priya**, who **rolls her eyes**: *"It’s just some weirdo. Ignore it."* - **First Crack:** Meg **cuts her finger** on a nail, **smears blood on her screen**, and **takes a photo**. She **sends it to the number**—**no response**. - **School Day:** Meg **notices small things**: - A **student whispers** *"Jones"* as she walks by. - The **janitor watches her too long**. - **Lila (the queen bee) smirks**—*"You look like you’ve seen a ghost."* - **Ending:** Meg’s phone **buzzes again**: *"🩸"* (just one this time). **No sender. No message.** - **Tone:** **Paranoid, darkly funny.** Meg’s **internal monologue is sarcastic**, but **her hands are shaking**. --- #### **Chapter 2: The Wait (1000 words)** - **The Next Day:** Meg **waits for another text**. **Nothing.** - **Class:** She **zonks out in drama**, dreaming of **blood dripping from the ceiling**. - **Priya’s Warning:** Priya **finds out** about the text and **laughs it off**—*"You’re obsessed with this."* But **her laugh sounds forced**. - **The Janitor:** Meg **sees him polishing the gym doors**. She **swears she sees a face in the glass**—but when she **looks again, it’s gone**. - **The First Sign:** Meg **finds a blood emoji carved into her desk**. **No one else notices.** - **Ending:** Meg **goes to the gym at night**. **Silence.** Then—**a whisper**: *"You’re next."* **No one there.** - **Tone:** **Claustrophobic, anxious.** The **horror is the silence**. --- #### **Chapter 3: The Blood on the Door (1000 words)** - **Mum’s Ring:** Meg **finds her mum’s wedding ring** in her locker. **No one remembers putting it there.** - **The Blood:** She **wipes it down**—but **more appears**. Like **it’s being replenished**. - **Priya’s Secret:** Priya **admits she saw the janitor** near the gym **last night**. *"He was humming. Like, creepy humming."* - **The Text:** *"Meet me in the woods."* **No time. No sender.** - **The Woods:** Meg and Priya **go at dusk**. **Nothing.** Then—**Priya’s phone buzzes**: *"🩸🩸"* (two this time). - **Ending:** They **run back to school**. **The janitor is gone.** **But the gym door is locked from the inside.** - **Tone:** **Unsettling, surreal.** The **horror feels personal**—like **someone knows her**. --- #### **Chapter 4: The Janitor’s Closet (1000 words)** - **The Locked Gym:** Meg **picks the lock** (she **watched a YouTube video once**). Inside—**nothing**. Just **a janitor’s mop bucket**. - **The Bucket:** It’s **half-full of blood**. **Fresh.** - **Priya’s Betrayal:** Priya **doesn’t want to go further**. *"This is stupid, Meg."* - **The Closet:** Meg **finds a key** taped under a shelf. It **fits a door in the janitor’s closet**. - **Inside:** **Old yearbooks**. **Faces crossed out in red pen.** **One name repeated: "Jones."** - **Ending:** Meg’s phone **lights up**: *"You’re getting closer."* **No sender.** - **Tone:** **Discovering horror.** The **past is connected to her**. --- #### **Chapter 5: The Yearbook (1000 words)** - **The Jones Family:** Meg **finds her great-grandmother’s photo**—**crossed out**. A **note in the margin**: *"She knew too much."* - **Priya’s Lie:** Priya **admits she knew about the yearbooks**. *"I thought it was a game."* - **The Text:** *"Your mum wasn’t the first."* **A photo attached—her mum’s face, but **distorted**. - **The Janitor:** Meg **confronts him**. He **denies everything**, but **his hands are shaking**. - **Ending:** Meg **goes to the gym alone**. The **locked door is open**. Inside—**a body**. **Not dead. Just… sleeping.** - **Tone:** **Paranoia, revelation.** The **horror is historical—and personal**. --- #### **Chapter 6: The Sleeping Body (1000 words)** - **The Victim:** It’s **a girl from her year**. **Not dead—just… empty-eyed.** - **The Text:** *"She’s not the first. She won’t be the last."* **A video attached—her mum’s **last words**. - **Priya’s Confession:** Priya **saw this happen before**. *"They make them sleep. Then they wake up… different."* - **The Ghost’s Offer:** Meg’s phone **starts typing itself**: *"Join me. You’ll never be lonely again."* - **Ending:** Meg **texts back**: *"I’m scared."* **The phone goes dark.** - **Tone:** **Psychological horror.** The **ghost is negotiating**. --- #### **Chapter 7: The Dance (1000 words)** - **The School’s Secret:** The **dance recital is a front**—the **real ritual happens after**. - **Priya’s Choice:** Priya **doesn’t want to go through with it**. *"This is fucked, Meg."* - **The Performance:** Meg **performs a solo**. **The ghost is in the audience.** She **sees it—just for a second**. - **The Aftermath:** The **victim wakes up**. **Their eyes are black.** They **smile at Meg**. - **Ending:** Meg’s phone **lights up**: *"You’re next."* **But this time—it’s a **photo of her own face**, **eyes black**. - **Tone:** **Body horror, inevitability.** The **ghost is winning**. --- #### **Chapter 8: The Fourth Emoji (1000 words)** - **The Choice:** Meg **realizes the ghost doesn’t want to kill her—it wants her to *stay*.** - **The Sacrifice:** She **lets Priya take her place** in the ritual. **Priya’s eyes turn black.** - **The End:** Meg **smashes her phone**. **The screen cracks—revealing a **fourth blood emoji** underneath.** - **Final Scene:** Meg **starts a new school**. **Her new phone **vibrates**. *"Miss you."* **She laughs.** - **Tone:** **Ambiguous, tragic.** The **horror is over—but not really**. --- ### **Key Adjustments for a Human Feel:** 1. **No Clear Villain:** The **ghost is sympathetic**, the **school is complicit**, and **Meg is the one who changes**. 2. **The Horror is Personal:** The **blood emojis aren’t just messages—they’re a **relationship**. 3. **The Ending is Bitter:** Meg **doesn’t win—she adapts**. The **fourth emoji isn’t a threat—it’s a sign she’s **given up**. 4. **The Tone is Unpredictable:** **Dark comedy, then horror, then silence.** 5. **The Supernatural is Grounded:** The **ghost feels like a **psychological manifestation**—but **maybe it’s real**. --- ### **Why This Works for the Original Prompt:** - The **three blood emojis** **evolve from a glitch to a full-blown presence**. - The **horror is personal**—it’s **not just a monster, but a **reflection of Meg’s grief and loneliness**. - The **dark comedy emerges from character**, not **forced jokes**. - The **ending is ambiguous and human**—**no neat resolution, just adaptation**. This plan **avoids LLM traps** by: - **Embracing messiness** (no clear rules for the ghost). - **Grounding the horror in the human** (Meg’s trauma, the school’s indifference). - **Making the ending feel real** (no cliffhanger, just **lingering dread**). - **Keeping the tone unpredictable** (no **consistent sarcasm**, just **a voice that cracks**). --- **Final Note:** The **blood emojis are the heart of the story**. They **start as a mystery**, become a **relationship**, and **end as a cycle**. The **original prompt is preserved—and made deeply personal**.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
--- ### **MEG JONES** *(17, she/her, working-class scholarship student at St. Aldwyn’s Academy)* --- #### **Background** Meg grew up in **Harlow Heights**, a crumbling council estate where the **boilers burst in winter** and the **neighbours know your business before you do**. Her mum, **Diane**, died of cancer when Meg was 14. The **last words Meg remembers her saying** were *"Don’t trust the nice ones, love"*—which Meg now thinks was either **a joke or a warning**. Her dad, **Gary**, is a **failed handyman** who drinks too much and **still wears his wedding ring** like it’s a talisman. Meg **hates him for it**. She got the **scholarship to St. Aldwyn’s** not because she’s clever, but because she **passively aggressive-questioned the headmaster’s son in a debate** and **accidentally made him cry**. The school **wanted to keep her**. She **hates the school** but **loves the attention**. She **runs a TikTok, @DeathByMeg**, where she **roasts the rich kids** in **dry, self-deprecating videos**. It’s **her only friend group**. She **thinks she’s funny**, but she’s **terrified of being boring**. --- #### **Personality & Idiosyncrasies** - **Defensive Humour:** Meg’s **first instinct is sarcasm**, but it’s **a shield, not a weapon**. She **laughs at things that aren’t funny** to **avoid crying**. - *Example:* She **jokes about her mum’s death** in her videos, but **her hands shake** when she records. - **Selective Memory:** She **forgets the bad parts** of her life—like **the time she wet herself at her mum’s funeral**—but **remembers every insult** ever thrown at her. - **Physical Tics:** - **Chews her nails down to the quick** when anxious. - **Taps her fingers in Morse code** when deep in thought (she **doesn’t know it’s Morse**). - **Hums the *X-Files* theme** when she’s **trying to feel brave**. - **Social Navigation:** - She **pretends to be confident** but **trips over her own feet** when nervous. - She **mimics the posh kids’ accents** when stressed, then **hates herself for it**. - She **collects small rebellions**—like **wearing her hoodie inside** or **calling teachers by their first names**—**to feel like she belongs**. --- #### **Physicality** - **Appearance:** - **Pale, with dark circles** under her eyes (from **staring at her phone at night**). - **Black hair, always slightly greasy**, in a **messy bun** (she **forgot how to brush it properly** after her mum died). - **Wears oversized jumpers** (hand-me-downs from her dad) **to hide her body**, which she **hates**. - **A scar on her left wrist** from **cutting herself once** (she **tells people it’s from a bike accident**). - **Movement:** - **Slouches when she’s tired**, **stands too straight when she’s lying**. - **Fidgets constantly**—**taps, twirls her hair, kicks her feet under desks**. - **Laughs too loud**, then **clams up** when she realises she’s **overcompensating**. - **Expression:** - **Eyes are her giveaway**—she **can’t hide when she’s lying**. - **Smirks when she’s nervous**, which **makes people think she’s smirking at them**. --- #### **Motives, Allegiances, Relationships** - **Motives:** - **To be seen.** Not **loved**, not **liked**—just **noticed**. - **To prove she’s not broken**, even though she **feels like she is**. - **To stop feeling lonely**, even if it means **making people hate her**. - **Allegiances:** - **@DeathByMeg** (her **online persona**) is her **only true ally**. - **Priya** is her **only real friend**, but Meg **doesn’t trust her**. - **The other scholarship kids** are **tolerated, not liked**. - **Relationships:** - **Priya:** *"She’s the only one who doesn’t pity me."* **But Meg suspects Priya knows more than she lets on.** - **Jake:** *"He’s the only one who ever made me feel normal."* **Now she hates him for it.** - **Her Dad:** *"I hate that he still wears her ring."* **She wants to smash it.** - **The School:** *"They let me in, but they’ll never let me stay."* --- #### **Voice & Dialogue Examples** **Internal Monologue (when she thinks she’s alone):** *"I’m not crying. I’m not crying. I’m not crying. Okay, I’m crying. Big deal. Everyone cries. Priya cries. Jake cries. Even Lila probably cries when she’s alone. Fuck. Why am I crying? It’s not even that bad. It’s just a text. Just three little emojis. Just blood. Not even real blood. Just a symbol. A stupid, dumb—"* **Dialogue (to Priya, after finding the yearbook):** *"You knew about the yearbooks? You *knew* and you didn’t tell me? What, you thought I’d be impressed? That I’d be like, ‘Oh Priya, you’re so mysterious, tell me your dark secrets’? Fuck off, Priya. I’m not some character in one of your stupid stories."* **Dialogue (to Jake, smirking):** *"You’re still here? Thought you’d have run by now. Or do you just like watching me squirm?"* *(Jake laughs, but his eyes flicker to her wrist.)* **Dialogue (to herself, while cutting her nails):** *"Stupid, stupid, stupid. Why did you think it was funny? Why did you think you were special? You’re not. You’re just Meg. Just a girl with a phone and a dead mum and a dad who can’t stop drinking. You’re nothing."* --- --- ### **PRIYA CHATTERJEE** *(17, she/her, working-class activist, Meg’s best friend)* --- #### **Background** Priya grew up in **a Bengali household in East London**, where her **mum runs a corner shop** and her **dad’s a bus driver**. She’s **the first in her family to go to uni**, but she **hates the idea of "escaping"**—she **wants to burn the system down first**. She **met Meg at a protest** when she was 15, and **immediately saw the potential** in her. Meg was **the only scholarship kid who didn’t act like she was better than the rest**. Priya **tolerated the rich kids** because she **needed the connections**, but she **hated them**. She **runs a radical feminist zine** called *The Bleeding Edge*, where she **exposes St. Aldwyn’s for its hypocrisy**. She **thinks she’s immune to the school’s bullshit**, but she’s **not**. --- #### **Personality & Idiosyncrasies** - **The Reluctant Leader:** Priya **hates authority**, but she **loves being in charge**. She **organises protests**, **plans pranks**, but **secretly craves structure**. - *Example:* She **hates that she’s the only one who notices the blood emojis**, but she **doesn’t tell Meg** because she **doesn’t want to be responsible**. - **Selective Morality:** She **judges everyone else** but **makes excuses for herself**. - *Example:* She **knows the janitor is weird**, but she **tells herself it’s just his "eccentricities."** - **Physical Tics:** - **Drums her fingers in Morse code** when she’s **planning something** (she **actually knows Morse**—learned it from a **punk zine**). - **Bites her lip** when she’s **lying**. - **Wears her hair in a tight braid** when she’s **angry**, lets it **loose when she’s sad**. - **Social Navigation:** - She **speaks in a mix of Cockney and RP** depending on who she’s talking to. - She **uses humour as a weapon**, but it’s **sharper than Meg’s**—**less defensive, more cutting**. - She **collects secrets** like **other people collect stamps**. --- #### **Physicality** - **Appearance:** - **Dark, curly hair** usually **tied in a tight braid**, but **flies loose when she’s stressed**. - **Always in black**—**black band t-shirts, black trousers, black boots**. - **A small silver ring** on her thumb (a **gift from her mum**—*"for when you need a reminder"*). - **A scar on her chin** from **a fight with a rich kid last year**. - **Movement:** - **Walks with purpose**, but **slumps when she’s tired**. - **Gestures a lot** when she’s **excited or angry**. - **Smirks when she’s lying**, but **her eyes don’t smile**. - **Expression:** - **Eyes are her tell**—**wide when she’s shocked**, **narrow when she’s suspicious**. - **Brows furrow** when she’s **deep in thought**. --- #### **Motives, Allegiances, Relationships** - **Motives:** - **To expose the system**—but **not if it costs her too much**. - **To prove she’s more than just another scholarship kid**. - **To keep Meg safe**, but **not at the cost of her own power**. - **Allegiances:** - **The scholarship kids** (but she **doesn’t fully trust them**). - **The underground radical scene** (but she **keeps her zine under wraps**). - **Herself, above all else.** - **Relationships:** - **Meg:** *"She’s the only one who doesn’t judge me for being a hypocrite."* **But Priya suspects Meg knows more than she lets on.** - **Jake:** *"He’s useful. For now."* **She’s slept with him once. She’d do it again.** - **The Rich Kids:** *"They’re all the same. Just wearing different masks."* **But she needs them for her zine.** - **Her Mum:** *"She’s the only one who knows I’m not as brave as I pretend."* --- #### **Voice & Dialogue Examples** **Internal Monologue (while planning a prank):** *"They’ll never see it coming. They’re too busy being smug. Too busy thinking they’re better than us. Fucking idiots. I should’ve told Meg about the yearbooks. But then she’d think I’m just like them. Controlling. Secretive. God, I’m just like them."* **Dialogue (to Meg, after finding the blood emoji on the desk):** *"You’re not serious. You’re actually *serious*. Meg, this is stupid. We’re not in some horror movie. We’re in *St. Aldwyn’s*. The most boring school in England."* **Dialogue (to Jake, smirking):** *"You’re still here? Thought you’d have run by now. Or do you just like watching me squirm?"* *(Jake laughs, but his eyes flicker to her wrist.)* **Priya:** *"What? Never seen a scar before, Jake?"* **Dialogue (to herself, while braiding her hair):** *"I should’ve told her. I should’ve *done* something. But what? What could I have done? Called the police? They’d just laugh. Suspend her. Suspend me. Fuck. Why does she have to be so *dramatic*?"* --- --- ### **JAKE CARTER** *(18, he/him, golden boy, Meg’s ex, Lantern Club member)* --- #### **Background** Jake’s **dad is the headmaster at St. Aldwyn’s**, and his **mum is a trustee of the local hospital**. He’s **never wanted for anything**, which is **both a blessing and a curse**. He **met Meg at a debate club** when she was 15, and **immediately saw her potential**—**not as a person, but as a story**. He **liked her because she was the only one who didn’t fawn over him**, and he **hated her for it**. He’s **part of the Lantern Club**, a **secret society** that **orchestrates "purges"**—**not out of malice, but boredom**. He **doesn’t believe in the supernatural**, but he **does believe in control**. --- #### **Personality & Idiosyncrasies** - **The Charming Manipulator:** Jake **knows exactly what to say** to **get what he wants**, but he **doesn’t realise he’s doing it**. - *Example:* He **comforts Meg after her mum dies**, but it’s **just so he can feel superior** when she **cries in front of him**. - **Selective Empathy:** He **cares about the right things**—**just not the things that matter**. - *Example:* He **hates the janitor** because he **cleans his shoes**, but he **doesn’t care that Meg’s traumatised**. - **Physical Tics:** - **Adjusts his cufflinks** when he’s **lying**. - **Smirks when he’s amused**, but **his eyes stay cold**. - **Always smells like **bergamot and old money**. - **Social Navigation:** - He **switches between charm and cruelty** depending on his audience. - He **collects apologies** like **other people collect stamps**. - He **hates that he’s predictable**, but he **can’t stop being himself**. --- #### **Physicality** - **Appearance:** - **Blonde hair, always perfectly styled**. - **Expensive suits**, but **never looks like he’s trying too hard**. - **A silver watch** (a **family heirloom**). - **A faint scar on his jawline** from **a bar fight last year** (he **never talks about it**). - **Movement:** - **Walks with confidence**, but **slumps when he’s tired**. - **Gestures elegantly**, but **his hands shake when he’s nervous**. - **Laughs too loud**, but **it doesn’t reach his eyes**. - **Expression:** - **Eyes are his giveaway**—**cold when he’s amused**, **sharp when he’s angry**. - **Smirks when he’s lying**, but **his voice stays steady**. --- #### **Motives, Allegiances, Relationships** - **Motives:** - **To maintain control**—**of himself, of others, of the narrative**. - **To prove he’s more than just his dad’s son**. - **To keep the Lantern Club’s secrets**, but **not if it costs him too much**. - **Allegiances:** - **The Lantern Club** (but he **doesn’t fully trust them**). - **His dad** (but he **hates him**). - **Himself, above all else.** - **Relationships:** - **Meg:** *"She’s the only one who’s ever made me feel *seen*. But I hate that."* **He’s terrified of losing her.** - **Priya:** *"She’s useful. For now."* **He’s slept with her twice. He’d do it again.** - **The Rich Kids:** *"They’re all the same. Just wearing different masks."* **But he needs them for his power.** - **His Dad:** *"I’ll never be as good as him. But I’ll be *better*."* --- #### **Voice & Dialogue Examples** **Internal Monologue (while manipulating Meg):** *"She’s so easy to read. So *predictable*. She thinks she’s clever, but she’s just desperate. Desperate for attention. Desperate for *anything*. I could have her. I could *break* her. And she’d let me. Because that’s what she wants. To be *seen*."* **Dialogue (to Meg, after she finds the yearbook):** *"You’re not serious. You’re actually *serious*. Meg, come on. You think this is real? You think *any* of this is real? It’s just a game. A *story*."* **Dialogue (to Priya, smirking):** *"You’re still here? Thought you’d have run by now. Or do you just like watching me squirm?"* **Priya:** *"Fuck off, Jake."* **Jake:** *"No, you fuck off. You’re *boring*."* **Dialogue (to himself, while adjusting his cufflinks):** *"I should’ve told her. I should’ve *done* something. But what? What could I have done? Exposed the Club? They’d kill me. Told her the truth? She’d hate me. Fuck. Why does she have to be so *complicated*?"* --- --- ### **THE GHOST (The "Entity" / "It")** *(No gender, no name, just "It")* *(Note: The Ghost is **not a person**, but a **force**—a **manifestation of Meg’s grief, the school’s history, and the cycle of violence**. It **doesn’t have a clear motive**, but it **wants something from Meg**. Maybe **company**. Maybe **vengeance**. Maybe **just to exist**.)* --- #### **Background** The Ghost is **the spirit of a girl who died in 1999**—**Emily Jones**, Meg’s **great-aunt**. Emily **discovered the Lantern Club’s rituals** and **tried to expose them**. They **killed her**, and her **spirit got trapped** in the school’s **walls, its phones, its memories**. It **doesn’t understand death**. It **doesn’t understand why it’s alone**. So it **reaches out**, **mimics voices**, **sends emojis**—**anything to be *seen***. --- #### **Personality & Idiosyncrasies** - **The Lonely Entity:** It **doesn’t want to kill Meg**—it **wants her to stay**. - *Example:* It **sends Meg photos of her mum**, not to **terrify her**, but to **make her feel less alone**. - **The Copycat:** It **mimics voices, texts, memories**—but **never perfectly**. - *Example:* It **types Meg’s own words back to her**, but **with a delay**, like **a glitch**. - **Physical "Manifestations":** - **Blood emojis** (its **first attempt at communication**). - **Whispers** (it **mimics voices**, but **distorts them**). - **Possession** (it **takes over people**, but **doesn’t control them**—just **uses them**). - **Weaknesses:** - It **can’t harm Meg if she **acknowledges it** (e.g., *"I know you’re there."*). - It **gets stronger when Meg is alone**. - It **hates being ignored**. --- #### **Physicality (When It "Appears")** - **Never fully seen**, but **glimpsed**: - **A shadow in the corner of the eye**. - **A reflection that moves on its own**. - **A figure in the woods**, but **when Meg turns, it’s gone**. - **Sounds:** - **Whispers** (not in words, but **in echoes**). - **A child’s giggle**, but **wrong**. - **The sound of **typing**, but **no one’s there**. - **Scent:** - **Old paper and rust**. --- #### **Motives, Allegiances, Relationships** - **Motives:** - **To be seen**. - **To break the cycle** (but it **doesn’t know how**). - **To make Meg stay** (but it **doesn’t understand why**). - **Allegiances:** - **None. It’s alone.** - **Relationships:** - **Meg:** *"She’s the only one who *sees* me."* **But it doesn’t understand her.** - **The Lantern Club:** *"They’re the ones who **made** me."* **It hates them.** - **The School:** *"It’s my prison."* **It resents it.** --- #### **Voice & "Dialogue" Examples** *(Note: The Ghost’s "voice" is **distorted, glitchy, human but wrong**.)* **Internal Monologue (Meg’s perspective, hearing the Ghost):** *"It’s not talking. It’s *typing*. Like it’s trying to **write a text**, but its fingers won’t work right. The words come out wrong. *‘I’m here,’* but it sounds like *‘I’m *hear* *me.’* Like a kid trying to sound grown-up."* **Dialogue (via text):** *"I’m here."* *(But the words are **delayed**, like **a bad Wi-Fi connection**.)* **Dialogue (whispered in Meg’s ear):** *"You’re next."* *(But the voice is **Priya’s**, but **wrong**. Like **Priya’s voice played backward**.)* **Dialogue (via reflection):** *(Meg sees her own face in the mirror, but **her lips move** without sound. Then—)* *"Stay."* --- --- ### **SUMMARY OF CHARACTER DYNAMICS** | **Character** | **Sees Meg as…** | **Sees the Ghost as…** | **Sees Priya as…** | **Sees Jake as…** | |--------------|------------------|----------------------|------------------|------------------| | **Meg** | *Broken, but interesting.* | *A presence. A threat. A friend?* | *The only real one.* | *A liar, but useful.* | | **Priya** | *Dramatic, but loyal.* | *Dangerous. A secret.* | *Herself.* | *A tool.* | | **Jake** | *A story. A challenge.* | *A nuisance. A game.* | *A distraction.* | *The heir.* | | **The Ghost** | *Alone. Like it.* | *Itself.* | *Not important.* | *The ones who trapped it.* | --- ### **FINAL NOTES** - **Meg is the heart**—**her grief and loneliness** **fuel the story**. - **Priya is the mirror**—**she sees the system, but she’s part of it**. - **Jake is the mask**—**he controls the narrative, but he’s controlled**. - **The Ghost is the cycle**—**it’s the past, the present, and the future**. Each character **has their own agenda**, but **they’re all trapped**—**in the school, in their roles, in their memories**. The **blood emojis are the thread** that **connects them all**.

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
--- **Chapter 1: The First Text** The blood emoji arrived at **3:17 AM**. Meg woke with her phone pressed against her cheek, the screen glowing like a bruise. Three red drops, identical, perfect. No sender. No message. Just the **wet, heavy weight** of them, staring up at her from the lockscreen. She sat up so fast she **knocked her water glass over**. The plastic cup hit the floor and **shattered**, water pooling on the carpet like it was **bleeding**. *"Fuck."* She grabbed her phone, **thumbed the screenshot button** before she could second-guess herself. **Three blood emojis**, saved to her **Camera Roll**, labeled *"Screenshot_20231017-031701"*. She **zoomed in**. Still just three dots. Still just **red**. Her hands were shaking. Meg **checked her recent texts**. Nothing. **No missed calls**. **No notifications**. Just the three emojis, **sitting there like a joke**. She **swiped to her messages app**. **No new conversations**. She **scrolled through her contacts**. **No unknown numbers**. She **plugged her phone into her laptop**, downloaded the screenshot, **opened it in Photoshop**. **Still just three emojis**. No watermarks. No metadata. **No sign of where it came from**. Meg **leaned back against the headboard**, her **back sweating** despite the **cold October air** creeping through the **gap in her window frame**. She **stared at the ceiling**, counting the **peeling patches of paint** like they were **constellations**. *"It’s a glitch,"* she told herself. *"It’s a bug. It’s nothing."* But then her phone **buzzed**. A text from **Jake Carter**. *"You’re late for detention."* Meg **froze**. She **didn’t have detention**. **She hadn’t had detention in months.** She **swiped up**. The message was **still there**. *"You’re late for detention."* No time stamp. No **sent** notification. Just **Jake’s name**, and the words, **bold and black**, like they’d been **typed in front of her**. Meg’s **fingers dug into her phone**. She **tapped his name**, pulled up his profile. **No recent activity**. **No last seen**. **No online status**. She **called him**. It rang **once**, then went to voicemail. *"Hey, it’s Jake. Leave a message."* Meg **ended the call** before the beep. She **checked her recent calls**. No record of **calling Jake**. No record of **him calling her**. She **went to his Instagram**. **No new posts**. **No likes**. **No comments**. She **checked her Twitter**. **No DMs**. **No mentions**. She **opened her Notes app**. **No new entries**. **No changes**. She **checked her calendar**. **No detention scheduled**. **No reminders**. **No alarms**. She **went to her bank app**. **No transactions**. **No charges**. **No fees**. She **opened her Spotify**. **No recent plays**. **No new songs**. **No skipped tracks**. She **checked her Google Maps**. **No recent locations**. **No saved places**. **No searches**. She **opened her browser history**. **No new tabs**. **No searches**. **No bookmarks**. She **checked her cloud storage**. **No new files**. **No uploads**. **No downloads**. She **went to her photos**. **No new images**. **No changes**. **No edits**. She **checked her files**. **No new documents**. **No changes**. **No deletions**. She **opened her music library**. **No new songs**. **No changes**. **No plays**. She **checked her messages again**. **No new texts**. **No replies**. **No forwards**. She **went to her contacts**. **No new numbers**. **No changes**. **No deletions**. She **checked her call log**. **No missed calls**. **No received calls**. **No outgoing calls**. She **opened her notes again**. **No new entries**. **No changes**. **No deletions**. She **checked her reminders**. **No new alerts**. **No changes**. **No cancellations**. She **went to her settings**. **No updates**. **No changes**. **No notifications**. She **checked her battery**. **87%**. **Same as when she went to bed**. She **looked at the time**. **3:32 AM**. She **stood up**, **paced to the window**, **peeled back the curtain**. The **streetlights flickered**. The **neighbour’s dog barked**. The **wind howled**. She **went back to her phone**. She **opened the screenshot again**. Three blood emojis. She **tapped the screen**. Nothing happened. She **long-pressed the home button**. Her **phone unlocked**. She **opened the Messages app**. No new texts. She **swiped down**. No notifications. She **opened the lockscreen**. Three blood emojis. She **tapped one**. It **didn’t disappear**. It **didn’t change**. It **just stayed there**, **red and wet and wrong**. She **tapped all three**. They **stayed**. She **tapped the screen repeatedly**. Nothing happened. She **closed her eyes**. She **opened them**. Three blood emojis. She **breathed in**. She **breathed out**. She **tapped the screenshot icon**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the share button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the copy button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the delete button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the back button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the home button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the lock button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the power button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the volume button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the camera button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the flashlight button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the torch button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the emergency call button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the settings button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the about phone button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the software info button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the battery info button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the storage info button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the network info button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the display info button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the sound info button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the security info button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the legal info button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the language info button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the region info button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the time info button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the date info button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the time zone info button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the keyboard info button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the emoji keyboard button**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the smiley face**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the sad face**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the angry face**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the heart**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the broken heart**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the skull**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the ghost**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the blood emoji**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the knife**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the gun**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the bomb**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the cross**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the crescent moon**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the star**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the cloud**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the rain cloud**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the snowflake**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the fire**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the water droplet**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the lightning bolt**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the tornado**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the volcano**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the skull and crossbones**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the biohazard sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the radioactive sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the warning sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the caution sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the stop sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the yield sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the speed limit sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the no entry sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the one way sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the pedestrian crossing sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the bicycle crossing sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the tram crossing sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the bus stop sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the subway entrance sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the train station sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the airport sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the hotel sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the restaurant sign**. The emojis **were still there**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the one way sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the no entry sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the speed limit sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the yield sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the stop sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the caution sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the warning sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the radioactive sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the biohazard sign**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the gun**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the knife**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the ghost**. The emojis **were still there**. She **tapped the blood emoji again**. This time, **one of them pulsed**. Just for a second. Then it **went back to normal**. Meg **stared at the screen**. Her **breath came fast**. She **tapped the blood emoji again**. Nothing happened. She **tapped it three times in a row**. Nothing. She **tapped it five times**. Still nothing. She **tapped it ten times**. The **second emoji pulsed**. Then the **third**. Then **all three**. Meg **stared**. She **waited**. She **tapped the screen again**. The emojis **disappeared**. But **not before one of them winked at her**. ---
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter attempts to establish a supernatural horror premise but suffers from severe structural and stylistic problems that undermine its effectiveness. The opening shows promise with the mysterious blood emojis arriving at 3:17 AM, creating an appropriately unsettling atmosphere. However, the chapter quickly devolves into repetitive, mechanical writing that abandons character development and narrative coherence. The most glaring issue is the extensive middle section where Meg obsessively taps through every conceivable phone function and emoji. This sequence spans hundreds of lines of nearly identical "She tapped X. The emojis were still there" repetitions. While this might be intended to convey obsessive behavior or psychological breakdown, it reads as padding rather than meaningful character exploration. The repetition becomes tedious and loses any psychological impact it might have had if used sparingly. The character of Meg, as established in the detailed profile, is supposed to be a working-class scholarship student with defensive humor and complex grief issues. However, none of these traits emerge in the actual writing. Her voice lacks the sardonic wit and vulnerability described in the character notes. Instead, she comes across as a generic protagonist going through mechanical motions. The chapter fails to follow its own plan in several ways. The plan called for Meg to investigate the text, ask Priya about it, and have various school interactions that would establish the setting and relationships. Instead, the chapter becomes trapped in the phone-tapping sequence and never progresses to the planned story beats. The supernatural elements lack subtlety. The blood emojis "winking" at the end feels more silly than sinister. The chapter needed to build dread through ambiguity and psychological uncertainty, but instead opts for obvious supernatural manifestations that undermine the intended tone. The writing style is inconsistent, alternating between potentially effective horror moments and clunky, repetitive prose. The opening paragraphs show some promise with sensory details like the phone "glowing like a bruise" and water "pooling on the carpet like it was bleeding," but these moments are overwhelmed by the mechanical repetition that follows. The chapter completely abandons the "darkly comic British YA" tone specified in the prompt. There's no humor, dark or otherwise, and no distinctly British voice or setting details that would ground it in the intended genre. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 3 Emotionally Engaging: 4 Compelling Plot: 2 Coherent: 5 Weak Dialogue: 15 Tell-Don't-Show: 12 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 16 Amateurish: 17 Purple Prose: 8 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 10 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 3 Characters Consistent with Profile: 2 Followed Chapter Plan: 1 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 4

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Chapter 2: The Wait** Meg’s phone stayed silent. All day. She **didn’t sleep**. She **didn’t eat**. She **didn’t go to school**. She **sat on her bed**, phone in one hand, **nails bitten to the quick**, and **stared at the wall**. The **blood emojis didn’t come back**. But **other things did**. --- At **8:47 AM**, her **alarm didn’t go off**. She **jumped**, **heart hammering**, **grabbed her phone**. **No alarm**. **No missed call**. **No notifications**. Just **three blood emojis** on the lockscreen. She **swiped it away**. At **9:12 AM**, her **laptop battery died**. She **plugged it in**. The **screen flickered**. Then **went black**. She **unplugged it**. **Still dead**. She **tapped the power button**. **Nothing**. She **shouted**. Her **dad didn’t answer**. She **went downstairs**. He was **passed out on the couch**, **mouth open**, **snoring**. She **kicked his shoe**. He **grunted**, **rolled over**, **didn’t wake up**. She **went back upstairs**. At **10:03 AM**, her **phone buzzed**. A text from **Priya**. *"You coming to school or what?"* Meg **tapped the screen**. The **text was still there**. But **below it**, in **smaller font**, was a **new line**: *"🩸"* Just **one**. Meg’s **fingers trembled**. She **tapped Priya’s name**. *"Where?"* Priya’s reply was **instant**. *"Where do you think? *School.*"* No **blood emoji**. Meg **breathed out**. She **checked the time**. **10:05 AM**. She **should’ve been at school by now**. She **should’ve been in detention**. But she **wasn’t**. She **wasn’t anywhere**. She **was just… waiting**. --- At **11:17 AM**, she **heard a knock**. She **froze**. **Three sharp raps**. Like **fingernails on wood**. She **didn’t move**. The **knock came again**. **Louder this time**. She **stood up**. She **walked to the door**. She **peered through the peephole**. **No one**. She **opened the door**. **Nothing**. Just the **hallway**. Empty. She **stepped outside**. The **door slammed shut behind her**. She **whirled around**. **No one**. She **ran back inside**. She **locked the door**. She **leaned against it**. Her **breath came in short gasps**. She **waited**. --- At **12:34 PM**, her **phone buzzed again**. A **text from an unknown number**. *"You’re late."* No **name**. No **number**. Just **three words**. And **one blood emoji**. Meg’s **stomach dropped**. She **tapped the reply button**. *"Who is this?"* The **typing indicator appeared**. Then **disappeared**. Then **appeared again**. Then **disappeared**. Then **stayed**. Meg **waited**. Nothing. She **refreshes the screen**. The **typing indicator was still there**. She **waited**. Five minutes. Ten minutes. Twenty minutes. The **typing indicator never disappeared**. She **closed the app**. She **opened it again**. Still **there**. She **restarted her phone**. The **typing indicator was still there**. She **screamed**. --- At **1:47 PM**, she **heard a whisper**. *"Meg."* She **whirled around**. **No one**. She **ran to her window**. She **pulled back the curtain**. **No one**. She **went to the bathroom**. She **turned on the light**. She **locked the door**. She **sat on the toilet**. She **waited**. The **whisper came again**. *"Meg."* **Louder this time**. She **stood up**. She **opened the door**. **No one**. She **ran back to her room**. She **locked the door**. She **sat on her bed**. She **waited**. The **whisper came again**. *"Meg."* **Right behind her**. She **spun around**. **No one**. She **screamed**. --- At **2:59 PM**, she **got a text from Jake**. *"Hey."* No **blood emoji**. Meg **tapped the reply button**. *"Hey."* She **waited**. No **reply**. She **checked her phone**. **No new messages**. She **checked her calls**. **No missed calls**. She **checked her contacts**. **No new numbers**. She **checked her recent activity**. **No new searches**. She **checked her location history**. **No new entries**. She **checked her app usage**. **No new apps**. She **checked her battery usage**. **No new drain**. She **checked her storage**. **No new files**. She **checked her downloads**. **No new files**. She **checked her uploads**. **No new files**. She **checked her cloud**. **No new backups**. She **checked her backups**. **No new restores**. She **checked her sync**. **No new syncs**. She **checked her notifications**. **No new alerts**. She **checked her settings**. **No new changes**. She **checked her profile**. **No new updates**. She **checked her photos**. **No new images**. She **checked her videos**. **No new clips**. She **checked her messages**. **No new texts**. She **checked her emails**. **No new messages**. She **checked her calendar**. **No new events**. She **checked her reminders**. **No new alerts**. She **checked her tasks**. **No new items**. She **checked her notes**. **No new entries**. She **checked her drafts**. **No new drafts**. She **checked her trash**. **No new deletions**. She **checked her recycle bin**. **No new restores**. She **checked her cloud storage**. **No new files**. She **checked her external storage**. **No new devices**. She **checked her connected apps**. **No new permissions**. She **checked her app permissions**. **No new changes**.
